title: Common response suggestion is sent to Google Analytics when user accepts duplicate comment Genius suggestion

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary**

It was found that although the `referrer-policy` header for https://hackerone.com/hacktivity was set to `strict-origin-when-cross-origin
`, a request to https://www.hackerone.com/blog contains full url path of the the hackivity page as the `referer` header eg. `https://hackerone.com/hacktivity?sort_type=popular&filter=type%3Aall&page=1&range=forever`. The `www.hackerone.com` being hosted on a third party, this can lead to private url information being passed to third party.    

**Description**

A `referrer policy` header is set on all pages including **/hacktivity** to `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` wherein the full path of the url will be set as the `referer` only if the request is `same-origin`. But it was seen that although this header being set at /hacktivity page, it still sends a full url to an different origin ie `www.hackerone.com`. www.hackerone.com being hosted on a third party and also even after setting the referrer-policy header the hacktivity page sends full url in the referer header. This is something serious here. 


**Steps to reproduce**

+ Sign-in to hackerone.
+ Start a web debugging proxy like burp to capture the request.
+ Click on hacktivity tab -  https://hackerone.com/hacktivity. The url will contain filter parameters that are set default eg `https://hackerone.com/hacktivity?sort_type=popular&filter=type%3Aall&page=1&range=forever`. This is the `popular` hackivity page with default filters. capture the request and response. The response looks like this.


```:status:                           200
date:                              Tue, 12 Dec 2017 05:42:21 GMT
content-type:                      text/html; charset=utf-8
cache-control:                     private, no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate
content-disposition:               inline; filename="response.html"
x-request-id:                      d7905553-8780-4731-93b8-021b4761817a
set-cookie:                        __Host-session=<Redacted value>; path=/; secure; HttpOnly
strict-transport-security:         max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload
expect-ct:                         enforce, max-age=86400
content-security-policy:           <Redacted as long for clarity>
referrer-policy:                   strict-origin-when-cross-origin
x-content-type-options:            nosniff
x-download-options:                noopen
x-frame-options:                   DENY
x-permitted-cross-domain-policies: none
x-xss-protection:                  1; mode=block
server:                            cloudflare-nginx
cf-ray:                            3cbe5c199a952db5-BOM
content-encoding:                  gzip```

**Note** - If we look at the `referrer-policy:` header it is set to `strict-origin-when-cross-origin`.

+ Click on `blog` link at the bottom of the page and capture the request. The request looks like this. 

```:method:         GET
:path:           /blog
:authority:      www.hackerone.com
:scheme:         https
user-agent:      Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; rv:46.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/46.0
accept:          text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
accept-language: en-US,en;q=0.5
accept-encoding: gzip, deflate, br
referer:         https://hackerone.com/hacktivity?sort_type=popular&filter=type%3Aall&page=1&range=forever
cookie:          <Redacted cookie values>
if-none-match:   "1513035467"```

**Note** - The `referer:` header contains the full url path inspite of referrer-policy header being set to strict-origin-when-cross-origin. This is a security violation as www.hackerone.com is not a `same-origin` and also hosted on a third party.

## Impact

The hackivity url does not contain any private or hidden paths. But even after a strict header being set, this behaviour is a threat as it violates the policy. If a header is set, the policy must be followed and enforced. This is to be ensured for better security.

activities.message:
The violation seems to exist at many more endpoints. 

This includes sandboxed program settings pages -
 
`https://hackerone.com/<program name>/edit` 

This can reveal names of sandboxed programs.

Hi @bigbug - thanks for letting us know. This is something the browser should implement and not something we can enforce. Also, I don't believe that this poses a risk that we're OK prioritizing now, but marking this as NMI to make sure we're not missing anything. Thanks!

@jobert

 About the browser implementation u mentioned. 

All other endpoints have also the same header set, but the browser follows the policy strictly. I do not think this is a browser issue. For eg. 

`https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=user&report_id=297181&view=custom&reported_to_team=&text_query=&program_states[]=2&program_states[]=3&program_states[]=4&program_states[]=5&sort_type=latest_activity&sort_direction=descending&limit=25&page=1#activity-2217787`

Let us take the above url itself. If I click on the Blog link as I have mentioned before the referer is set to `https://www.hackerone.com` only. 

Both endpoints have same values set for `referrer-policy` header ie `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` but behaves differently. This is definitely not a browser issue.

@jobert 

About the risk, the hackivity url does not have a high impact but the program edit pages can reveal sandboxed program names. This should be considered as the program names are sent to a third party site.

But, shouldn't the browser make sure that the referrer isn't sent to www.hackerone.com? It actually might be expected behavior because the header is set on hackerone.com (no subdomain) and links to a subdomain (www.hackerone.com). This is merely a missing best practice and doesn't strike me as a security vulnerability. We're not leaking any confidential data since www.hackerone.com is also under our management. What is the fix here?
@jobert The best fix could be  setting a `no referer` header. This wouldn't send any referers at all.

@jobert 

I would like to point out the same in case of `google analytics` too. 

If we click a program settings page the url reveals the name of sandboxed program to google analytics. 

eg. I have a test program named `bigbug_test`. If I click the settings, the url would look like `https://hackerone.com/bigbug_test_hp00w/edit`

A corresponding google analytics request is sent for this as follows: 

>:method: POST
:path: /r/collect
:authority: www.google-analytics.com
:scheme: https
user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; rv:46.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/46.0
accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
accept-language: en-US,en;q=0.5
accept-encoding: gzip, deflate, br
content-type: text/plain
referer: https://hackerone.com/bigbug_test_hp00w/edit
content-length: 663
origin: https://hackerone.com

>v=1&_v=j66&a=2145669889&t=pageview&_s=1&dl=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbigbug_test_hp00w%2Fedit&dr=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbugs%3Fsubject%3Duser%26report_id%3D297181%26view%3Dcustom%26reported_to_team%3D%26text_query%3D%26program_states%255B%255D%3D2%26program_states%255B%255D%3D3%26program_states%255B%255D%3D4%26program_states%255B%255D%3D5%26sort_type%3Dlatest_activity%26sort_direction%3Ddescending%26limit%3D25%26page%3D1&ul=en-us&de=UTF-8&dt=Security%20Page%20Settings&sd=24-bit&sr=1525x858&vp=1525x734&je=1&_u=SCCAAUAj~&jid=961500536&gjid=1327130342&cid=814593961.1510427630&uid=193109&tid=UA-49905813-1&_gid=1323093568.1512929475&_r=1&z=712687688

If you notice the body of the request sent to google analytics, the `dl` parameter contains the sandboxed program name - `dl=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbigbug_test_hp00w%2Fedit`

https://www.google-analytics.com is an external domain and program names shouldn't be send to other sites.

**Note** - Also have a look at the `referer header` here. The request sent to google analytics contains full url including program name. - `https://hackerone.com/bigbug_test_hp00w/edit`
`https://www.google-analytics.com` is not maintained by hackerone and thus should be considered as a security issue.

Hi @bigbug - I was able to reproduce the behavior, but only across subdomains. We're OK with this for the time being and won't be prioritizing a fix for this. Thanks again for bringing this to our attention. Happy hacking!

We've accepting those in the past when, for example, a password reset token was sent to GA. We're OK with program handles because it's impossible to determine whether it's a sandboxed or launched program.

@jobert These are some endpoints that came into notice. There may or may not be more of them. But it is definitely needed to fix this as `referrer-policy` violations can leak private information. Atleast to tighten the security. 

Also sending infromation to external domains are really not a positive behaviour. According to me this needs a fix. 

The google analytics requests also contained bounty suggestion information. 
While setting bounty the suggestions would appear. And on clicking the suggested bounty, the actual  bounty value is send to the google analytics. Isn't that considered as a threat?
No, thanks for asking, but it isn't at this point!

@jobert Are you sure? Not even the name of the program, along with the report number and the bounty amount? 

`v=1&_v=j66&a=459584654&t=event&_s=2&dl=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbugs%3Fsubject%3Dbigbug_test_hp00w&dr=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbugs%3Fsubject%3Duser%26report_id%3D297181%26view%3Dcustom%26reported_to_team%3D%26text_query%3D%26program_states%255B%255D%3D2%26program_states%255B%255D%3D3%26program_states%255B%255D%3D4%26program_states%255B%255D%3D5%26sort_type%3Dlatest_activity%26sort_direction%3Ddescending%26limit%3D25%26page%3D1&ul=en-us&de=UTF-8&dt=Inbox%20-%20HackerOne&sd=24-bit&sr=1525x858&vp=1525x734&je=1&ec=Recommendation%20for%20bounty&ea=click&el=Recommendation%20clicked%20on%20Report%20%23296709%20for%20team%20bigbug_test_hp00w%3A%20Median%20recommendation%20(50th%20percentile)%20for%20a%20medium%20severity.&ev=150&_u=SCCAAUAj~&jid=1689943702&gjid=327599366&cid=814593961.1510427630&uid=193109&tid=UA-49905813-1&_gid=1323093568.1512929475&_r=1&z=1404962091`

This is how the request body looks like. Please have a look at the `el` and `ev` parameters - 

`el=Recommendation%20clicked%20on%20Report%20%23296709%20for%20team%20bigbug_test_hp00w%3A%20Median%20recommendation%20(50th%20percentile)%20for%20a%20medium%20severity.&ev=150`

This clearly have report number and bounty value.
**Isn't disclosing program name, report numbers and bounty values considered as a threat?**
We might look at that in the future, but I don't believe it warrants any additional attention at this point.

@jobert Don't mind. But if you are disclosing the program name, the associated report number along with the bounty you offered and the severity to a third party and still you don't consider it for a fix. What could be more severe?
Information like private report content, certain invitation tokens, password reset tokens, etc.
@jobert If I was hosting a private program on hackerone and such sensitive issues are sent to a third party, then how is the program private anymore?
I'm not saying it is, I'm saying that we would fix IF information like that would've been sent to a third party. But, you haven't demonstrated that yet.
@jobert I have demonstrated the same for a sandboxed program. Isn't the same applicable for a private program?
We don't consider the program handles or bounty amounts to fall in that bucket.
@jobert Can I point out a non-security issue here? As I have found it? Is it ok?
Please submit those to support@hackerone.com. Thanks!

@jobert I just noticed that the google analytics request contains a `uid` parameter which is actually the `_id` of a user that has created the program. This could leak information about the creator or the owner of the program, regardless of program state. Could you look into this?
@jobert A small correction. The `uid` parameter will contain the `_id` of the logged in user. This can leak ids of all the users those are associated with a program ie. `team members`.
@jobert This way it is possible to enumerate team members of a program.
@jobert Request you to look into this! thanks
Anything on this?

@jobert 

As you have already mentioned, any kind of `program content` is considered sensitive. I found one such scenario among the google analytics request. 

While trying to create a new `common response`,  an `accept path` is returned that contains `base64` of the already typed message 
eg. if I typed `@aorta ?` as the message, the accept path returned would be as follows: 

`{"accept_path":"/bigbug_test_hp00w/common_responses/new?message=QGFvcnRhID8%3D"}`

 `QGFvcnRhID8%3D` is the base64 of `@aorta ?`. 

It was seen that google analytics contains the full `accept path` as one of its parameters. 

`v=1&_v=j66&a=1727450351&t=pageview&_s=1&dl=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbigbug_test_hp00w%2Fcommon_responses%2Fnew%3Fmessage%3DQGFvcnRhID8%253D&dr=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbugs%3Fsubject%3Dbigbug_test_hp00w%26report_id%3D296709%26view%3Dnew%26substates%255B%255D%3Dnew%26reported_to_team%3D%26text_query%3D%26program_states%255B%255D%3D2%26program_states%255B%255D%3D3%26program_states%255B%255D%3D4%26program_states%255B%255D%3D5%26sort_type%3Dlatest_activity%26sort_direction%3Ddescending%26limit%3D25%26page%3D1&ul=en-us&de=UTF-8&dt=Add%20Common%20Responses&sd=24-bit&sr=1525x858&vp=1525x734&je=1&_u=SCCAAUAj~&jid=1843720938&gjid=712444887&cid=814593961.1510427630&uid=193109&tid=UA-49905813-1&_gid=1323093568.1512929475&_r=1&z=707970596` 

Please have a look at the `dl` parameter - `dl=https%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fbigbug_test_hp00w%2Fcommon_responses%2Fnew%3Fmessage%3DQGFvcnRhID8%253D`

This leaks the typed message in `message`  parameter in base64 format which is set as `common response`.

**IMPACT**
+ Thus common responses of programs are leaked to google analytics. 
+ This also happens to be private content of the reports that are typed.
Hence this is a private information leakage. Hope you consider this! 

thank you
@jobert Anything on this?
Fair enough, I'd say that qualifies. We'll triage this.
We have successfully reproduced the behavior you described and are currently working on a fix. Thanks for submitting!
@jobert Thank you for confirming that. Sorry it took a little time to bring this to your notice. thank you for your patience!
Hi @jobert Any updates?

It's only been a day, @bigbug. This behavior is undesirable and I'd advice you not to ask for updates so soon after a report has been triaged. You're here to show your professionalism as a hacker, so please act like one. This particular issue is not a high priority for our team to pick up. We might get to it next week. We'll get back to you when we have an update or any questions. Thanks for your understanding.

Hi @jobert, 

I would like to share a piece of information on this at this moment.  

The Hackbot feature **Same comment twice** seems to be broken at this point of time. Although this setting is turned on, there is no suggestion shown to create a new common response, when we type a comment more than once. I presume this is an intentional behavior and is a part of the fix you are working on.  If not please have a look into this as well! 

Hope this helps!

Hi @bigbug - thanks for flagging, we'll pass it along to our engineering team to see if they can reproduce. Minor side note: if you believe you have found a functional bug, please reach out to support@hackerone.com. They'll be able to assist you and get it in the hands of the right people. Thanks for your understanding!

Hi @jobert greetings of the season! 

I thought of mentioning it here, as it was related to the current report. 

Could you tell me if **errors.hackerone.net** is in the scope? This is used to report CSP violations and other javascript related errors. So could you confirm if sending sensitive information to this domain would be considered as a security threat or not?
It isn't in scope and maintained by us, so sensitive information being sent there is OK.
@jobert Could you please edit the title to something relevant? The current title of this report is quite misleading. Thanks!

additional_data.new_title: Common response suggestion is sent to Google Analytics when user accepts duplicate comment Genius suggestion

activities.message: Hi @jobert this is just to confirm from my end that the common response suggestion is up and working now, as expected. Can fix be expected soon?
Hi @bigbug, we are still investigating this. Thus I cannot give you an estimate on a fix. Thanks for being patient with us.
Thanks for the bounty!

Hey @bigbug,

We're currently in the final stages of testing and review for the fix, so we should be able to resolve this report soon! thank you for your patience!
Great! Thanks for the update @dirk.

Hi @bigbug,

The fix for the issue should be in production now. Can you verify that it works?

Hi @iaslamov,

The request to google analytics still contains the  common response in base64 encoded format as a part of the `dl` parameter.

Blimey! Can you please post an actual request with the body?

When I check the request I see the following:
https://www.google-analytics.com/collect
v=1&_v=j66&a=770846648&t=pageview&_s=1&dl=http%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Fteam-name%2Fcommon_responses%2Fnew%3Fmessage%3DFILTERED&dr=http%3A%2F%2Fhackerone.com%2Freports%2F97&ul=en-us&de=UTF-8&dt=Add%20Common%20Responses&sd=24-bit&sr=2560x1440&vp=1057x1259&je=0&_u=SCCAAUAj~&jid=&gjid=&cid=2023694146.1516301754&uid=771&tid=UA-49905813-1&_gid=1361136293.1516301754&z=1620981409
- note the FILTERED message string in it

Hi @iaslamov,

Sorry for the delay. The request no more contains the common response. Instead replaced by FILTERED. Looks great :) 

I can confirm its fixed!
Can we disclose this?
